Microbenchmarks indicate a noticeable increase in locks but no direct performance impact. Can you summarize if this has any impact on application-level benchmarks?
Currently running the application benchmarks, I'll update this PR with the data.

Since these classes are always per-RPC, could we just add to the documentation that they cannot be created before gRPC is initialized? There are lots of object that are created before the contexts that also ensure lib is initialized (CompletionQueue, CallCreds, ChannelCreds, ...)

What is the motivation for adding them to ctx?

AFAIK, grpc initialization is not something C++ users do explicitly, but rather depend on the behavior that creating high level objects like CompletionQueue will initialize the library for them.

Its a thorny API to say "make sure you have an active CompletionQueue (or CallCreds/Server/...) when you initialize a client or server context".

This is especially challenging for destruction.  Its pretty tricky to enforce a destruction order that makes sure all contexts are destroyed before all long lived objects.

Unless this is affecting a real user, and there is no other way to fix, I don't think we should add an unconditional lock of `g_init_mu` on every RPC.

`GrpcLibraryInitializer` is already public, right? Wouldn't that accomplish this goal?

This is impacting an internal user getting TSAN failures.

```GrpcLibraryInitializer``` doesn't actually call ```grpc_init```.  AFAIK, ```GrpcLibraryCodegen``` is the only thing responsible for that.

I agree that we shouldn't have a global mutex on each one of these calls (maybe we can switch it to an atomic?) 

@vjpai 
Do you see some way we can push initialization onto the user that I'm missing?
